page.title: Adverbs and AdvP
page.introduction:
Adverbs express four basic types of information:
time,
location,
manner, and
reason or purpose.
These types have different characteristics as to which positions they may occupy and how they may be modified, so they need to be distinguished from each other by a feature. We’ll deal with each in turn.

Temporal adverbs include the English words: already, then, soon, now, later, and always. Many languages also have a negative temporal adverb meaning ‘no time’, such as never in English. Think of similar words in your language.
These need to be distinguished from other types of words or phrases that can also express the time in a sentence, such as: nominal phrases yesterday, last night, next year, tomorrow, a long time ago; prepositional phrases for a long time, in a little while, at 10 o’clock; and adverbial clauses while you are working, when Sue arrived.
